   Assessment and Plan:
   42 year old female with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis who presented
   with acute fulminant hepatic failure with multiple electrolyte
   abnormalities, confusion, fevers, & lactate elevation
   .
   #Alcoholic hepatitis:
   Ultrasound with poor study but patent vasculature and no overt ascites
   noted.  Discriminate function is 63 on admit.  Estimated mortality
   given her degree of elevation in the presence of encephalopathy is on
   the order of 45%.  Bilirubin continues to climb.
   - continue steroids d5
   - continue  pentoxiphylline
   - continue tube feeds via OGT
   - liver recs appreciated
   - trend LFTs, synthetic function daily
   - f/up liver recs, appreciate input
   .
   # Encephalopathy: Most consistent with hepatic encephalopathy and EtoH
   withdrawal. Recent CT head without evidence of any bleeding.
   - continue lactulose and rifaximin
   - try to limit  Fentanyl  and d/c her propofol at this point
   .
   # EtoH withdrawal:
   - Ativan drip to max 8mg/hr now , will wean today
   - now off of propofol completely
   - basal Fentanyl with boluses as needed /  weaning slowly as tolerates
   - continue on haldol 2mg q8h standing, monitor QTC
   - continue mvt/thiamine/folate
   - social work input appreciated, will continue to follow
   .
   #Stool changes: stools more odorous and discolored today. [**Month (only) 11**] just
   simply be lactulose effects and hyperbilirubinemia vs.  recent
   antibiotics with ceftriaxone.
   - will send off C.difficile
   .
   #Electrolyte abnormalities: Chronic issue even as outpatient as she has
   need for Mg and K repletion at home. She has been having low Phos, Mg,
   K  in setting of worse liver failure
   --Will continue to check [**Hospital1 **] lytes and replete as needed
   .
   # Anemia:
   Pt with baseline anemia, also h/o BRBPR at home though none here. Had
   some oral trauma in setting of intubation causing some additional blood
   loss.
   - active type and screen, transfuse hct>21 or active bleeding
   - check Hcts daily
   - continue PPI
   - stool guaiacs
   .
   # Ventilation:
   Overbreathing slightly but will allow given metabolic acidosis.  CXRs
   have been  clear. She had been intubated for airway protection / AMS.
   - Did not tolerate PSV well so will continue to rest on A/C for today
   to maintain safe airway given extreme AMS and encephalopathy.
   .
   # Increased secretions/ recent fevers:  No current leukocytosis or
   fevers and lactate elevation has now corrected so may not be any clear
   infection.  Intubation with AMS on admission so need to be weary of
   aspiration PNAs and VAP.
   -CIS, low threshold to cover with Abx / holding off for now
   -f/up sputum, blood cultures
   -follow CXRs for interval changes
   .
   # Conjunctivitis: Eyes with bilateral yellowish-green thick secretions
   along conjunctivae when admitted.  Much improved eye exam with no
   crusting today.
   -erythromycin eye ointment QID ( day 5 of 7 )
   -continue to monitor ; improving
   .
   # peripheral neuropathy
   - holding gabapentin for now given sedated
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:  OG tube feeds
   Glycemic Control:   continue FSG checks, Humalog PRN for now

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information:

The patient is a 42-year-old female with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis who presented with acute fulminant hepatic failure, multiple electrolyte abnormalities, confusion, fevers, and lactate elevation. She has been intubated for airway protection and has been receiving various medications to manage her symptoms.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.3°C
* Heart rate: 88 bpm
* Blood pressure: 112/63 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 23 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 98%
* White blood cell count: 9.9 x 10^9/L

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Bilirubin: 38 μmol/L (elevated)
* Lactate: 1.5 mmol/L (elevated)
* INR: 1.5 (elevated)
* Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL (normal)
* Glucose: 117 mg/dL (normal)
* Electrolyte levels: potassium 3.6 mmol/L, sodium 114 mmol/L, chloride 25.3 mmol/L

The patient has been diagnosed with C. difficile infection, which has been treated with antibiotics. She has also been diagnosed with respiratory failure and is receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's physical examination shows:

* Intubated and sedated
* Bilateral yellowish-green thick secretions along the conjunctivae
* Odorous and discolored stools

The patient's medical history includes:

* Alcoholic cirrhosis
* Chronic liver failure
* Chronic anemia
* Recent hospitalization for alcoholic hepatitis

The patient's current medications include:

* Fentanyl
* Lorazepam
* Pantoprazole
* Heparin
* Protonix
* Humalog
* Gabapentin

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue steroids and pentoxiphylline for liver failure
* Continue tube feeds via OG tube
* Monitor LFTs and synthetic function daily
* Follow up with liver specialists
* Continue lactulose and rifaximin for encephalopathy
* Try to limit fentanyl and discontinue propofol
* Continue Ativan drip and wean slowly
* Continue basal fentanyl with boluses as needed
* Continue haloperidol and monitor QTc
* Continue to monitor electrolyte levels and replete as needed
* Continue to monitor Hct and transfuse as needed
* Continue to monitor CXRs for interval changes

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Hepatic encephalopathy
* EtoH withdrawal
* Infection (C. difficile, pneumonia, etc.)
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Electrolyte imbalances
* Anemia
* Thrombocytopenia
* Hepatorenal syndrome
* Hepatic failure

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and physical examination to detect any potential complications early on and adjust the plan of care accordingly.

   42 year old female with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis who presented

   abnormalities, confusion, fevers, & lactate elevation
   .
   #Alcoholic hepatitis:

   .

   - now off of propofol completely
   - basal Fentanyl with boluses as needed /  weaning slowly as tolerates
   - continue on haldol 2mg q8h standing, monitor QTC
   - continue mvt/thiamine/folate
   - social work input appreciated, will continue to follow
   .
   #Stool changes: stools more odorous and discolored today. [**Month (only) 11**] just
   simply be lactulose effects and hyperbilirubinemia vs.  recent
   antibiotics with ceftriaxone.

   K  in setting of worse liver failure
   --Will continue to check [**Hospital1 **] lytes and replete as needed
   .

   Pt with baseline anemia, also h/o BRBPR at home though none here. Had
   some oral trauma in setting of intubation causing some additional blood
   loss.
   - active type and screen, transfuse hct>21 or active bleeding
   - check Hcts daily
   - continue PPI
   - stool guaiacs
   .

   Overbreathing slightly but will allow given metabolic acidosis.  CXRs
   have been  clear. She had been intubated for airway protection / AMS.
   - Did not tolerate PSV well so will continue to rest on A/C for today
   to maintain safe airway given extreme AMS and encephalopathy.
   .
   # Increased secretions/ recent fevers:  No current leukocytosis or
   fevers and lactate elevation has now corrected so may not be any clear
   infection.  Intubation with AMS on admission so need to be weary of
   aspiration PNAs and VAP.

   -f/up sputum, blood cultures
   -follow CXRs for interval changes
   .

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 42-year-old female with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis who presented with acute fulminant hepatic failure, multiple electrolyte abnormalities, confusion, fevers, and lactate elevation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Lactate level has decreased to 1.5 mmol/L, but bilirubin remains elevated at 38 mg/dL.
* INR has improved, and Hct is stable at 25-26%.
* The patient is intubated and sedated, with a respiratory rate of 23 inspirations per minute and a SpO2 of 98%.
* The patient has a history of encephalopathy, EtoH withdrawal, and is at risk for aspiration pneumonia and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
* The patient has a bilateral yellowish-green thick secretion in the conjunctivae, which is improving with erythromycin eye ointment.
* The patient has a history of peripheral neuropathy, but gabapentin is being held due to sedation.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

* Further deterioration of liver function, leading to increased risk of bleeding, encephalopathy, and death.
* Development of sepsis or septic shock due to the patient's immunocompromised state and the presence of C. difficile toxin in the stool.
* Aspiration pneumonia or VAP due to the patient's intubation and sedation.
* Increased risk of bleeding due to the patient's coagulopathy and thrombocytopenia.
* Further electrolyte abnormalities, particularly hyperkalemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypomagnesemia.
* Development of acute kidney injury or acute tubular necrosis due to the patient's liver failure and electrolyte abnormalities.
* Increased risk of respiratory failure due to the patient's respiratory acidosis and the presence of C. difficile toxin in the stool.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continuing steroids, pentoxiphylline, and tube feeds via OGT.
* Monitoring LFTs and synthetic function daily.
* F/up liver recs and appreciating input.
* Continuing lactulose and rifaximin for encephalopathy.
* Weaning off propofol and Fentanyl, and monitoring QTC.
* Continuing haldol, mvt/thiamine/folate, and social work input.
* Sending off C. difficile toxin A and B tests.
* Repleting electrolytes as needed.
* Transfusing blood products as necessary.
* Monitoring Hcts daily.
* Continuing PPI.
* Stool guaiacs.
* Maintaining a safe airway with A/C and low threshold to cover with antibiotics.
* F/up sputum, blood cultures, and CXRs for interval changes.
* Continuing erythromycin eye ointment for conjunctivitis.
* Holding gabapentin for now due to sedation.

   - Ativan drip to max 8mg/hr now , will wean today

   - continue on haldol 2mg q8h standing, monitor QTC

   - will send off C.difficile

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 42-year-old female with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis who presented with acute fulminant hepatic failure, multiple electrolyte abnormalities, confusion, fevers, and lactate elevation.

The patient's current condition is:

* Respiratory: Intubated, sedated, and ventilated with a respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%.
* Cardiovascular: Hemodynamically stable with a blood pressure of 112/63 mmHg and a heart rate of 88 beats per minute.
* Neurological: Encephalopathic with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of unknown, and a recent CT head without evidence of bleeding.
* Gastrointestinal: Altered mental status, increased abdominal distension, and stools more odorous and discolored today.
* Hematological: Anemic with a hemoglobin level of 7.4 g/dL and a platelet count of 146 K/uL.
* Renal: Serum creatinine level of 0.9 mg/dL and a urine output of 2,375 mL.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

* Hepatic encephalopathy: Most consistent with hepatic encephalopathy and EtoH withdrawal.
* Electrolyte abnormalities: Chronic issue even as an outpatient, including hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypomagnesemia.
* Anemia: Baseline anemia with a hemoglobin level of 7.4 g/dL and a platelet count of 146 K/uL.
* Increased secretions and recent fevers: No current leukocytosis or fevers, but may be at risk for aspiration pneumonia and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
* Conjunctivitis: Bilateral yellowish-green thick secretions along the conjunctivae when admitted, but much improved eye exam today.
* Peripheral neuropathy: Holding gabapentin for now given sedated.

The patient is currently receiving the following medications:

* Fentanyl (concentrate) infusion at 75 mcg/hour
* Lorazepam (Ativan) infusion at 8 mg/hour
* Pantoprazole (Protonix) 40 mg PO daily
* Heparin sodium (prophylaxis) 5,000 units SQ every 8 hours
* Mvt/thiamine/folate supplements
* Erythromycin eye ointment QID (day 4 of 7)

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Bilirubin level of 38 mg/dL
* LFTs elevated, but INR improved
* Hct stable at 25-26%
* WBC count of 9.9 K/uL
* Platelet count of 146 K/uL
* Creatinine level of 0.9 mg/dL
* Urine output of 2,375 mL
* Lactic acid level of 1.5 mmol/L
* Albumin level of 2.5 g/dL
* LDH level of 663 IU/L
* Ca++ level of 8.5 mg/dL
* Mg++ level of 2.2 mg/dL
* PO4 level of 3.2 mg/dL

The patient's diagnosis is:

* Acute fulminant hepatic failure with multiple electrolyte abnormalities, confusion, fevers, and lactate elevation
* Hepatic encephalopathy
* Electrolyte abnormalities
* Anemia
* Increased secretions and recent fevers
* Conjunctivitis
* Peripheral neuropathy

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continue steroids d5
* Continue pentoxiphylline
* Continue tube feeds via OGT
* Liver recs appreciated
* Trend LFTs, synthetic function daily
* F/up liver recs, appreciate input
* Continue lactulose and rifaximin
* Try to limit Fentanyl and d/c propofol at this point
* Wean Ativan drip to max 8 mg/hr now, and wean Fentanyl slowly as tolerated
* Continue on haldol 2mg q8h standing, monitor QTC
* Continue mvt/thiamine/folate
* Social work input appreciated, will continue to follow
* Send off C.difficile toxin A & B test
* Continue to check hospital lytes and replete as needed
* Active type and screen, transfuse Hct >21 or active bleeding
* Check Hcts daily
* Continue PPI
* Stool guaiacs
* Continue erythromycin eye ointment QID (day 4 of 7)
* Hold gabapentin for now given sedated

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Aspiration pneumonia
* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
* Hepatic encephalopathy
* Electrolyte abnormalities
* Anemia
* Increased secretions and recent fevers
* Conjunctivitis
* Peripheral neuropathy

The patient's disposition is currently ICU care with ongoing monitoring and management of her medical complications.

The patient is a 42-year-old female with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis who presented with acute fulminant hepatic failure, multiple electrolyte abnormalities, confusion, fevers, and lactate elevation. She is currently intubated and sedated in the ICU. Her liver function tests (LFTs) continue to worsen, and her bilirubin levels are climbing. She has been diagnosed with encephalopathy, likely due to hepatic encephalopathy and ethanol withdrawal. She is being treated with lactulose and rifaximin, and her propofol has been discontinued. She has also been started on a tapering dose of steroids and pentoxiphylline.

The patient has several potential medical complications that need to be monitored and managed:

1. Infection: The patient has a history of C. difficile infection, which is currently being treated. She also has a risk of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to her intubation.
2. Electrolyte abnormalities: The patient has chronic electrolyte abnormalities, including hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia, which need to be closely monitored and managed.
3. Encephalopathy: The patient's encephalopathy is likely due to hepatic encephalopathy and ethanol withdrawal, and it needs to be closely monitored and managed.
4. Anemia: The patient has a baseline anemia, and her hemoglobin levels need to be closely monitored and managed.
5. Ventilation: The patient is intubated and requires mechanical ventilation. She has a risk of developing overbreathing, which needs to be closely monitored and managed.
6. Conjunctivitis: The patient has bilateral conjunctivitis, which is being treated with erythromycin eye ointment.
7. Peripheral neuropathy: The patient has a history of peripheral neuropathy, which is being managed with gabapentin.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a risk of developing sepsis due to her underlying liver disease and potential infections.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient has a risk of developing respiratory failure due to her underlying lung disease and potential complications from mechanical ventilation.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient has a risk of developing cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, due to her underlying liver disease and potential electrolyte imbalances.
4. Renal failure: The patient has a risk of developing renal failure due to her underlying liver disease and potential electrolyte imbalances.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a risk of developing gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding, due to her underlying liver disease and potential infections.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and manage potential medical complications.

   42 year old female with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis who presented
   with acute fulminant hepatic failure with multiple electrolyte
   abnormalities, confusion, fevers, & lactate elevation
   .
   #Alcoholic hepatitis:
   Ultrasound with poor study but patent vasculature and no overt ascites
   noted.  Discriminate function is 63 on admit.  Estimated mortality
   given her degree of elevation in the presence of encephalopathy is on
   the order of 45%.  Bilirubin continues to climb.
   - continue steroids d4, pentoxiphylline
   - continue tube feeds via OGT
   - liver recs appreciated
   - trend LFTs, synthetic function daily
   - liver recs appreciated, f/up additional input
   - no clear evidence of infection (no infiltrate, blood and urine cx
   unremarkable) therefore stopped ceftriaxone yesterday
   .
   # Encephalopathy:
   Most consistent with hepatic encephalopathy and EtoH withdrawal. CT
   head without evidence of any bleeding.
   - continue lactulose and rifaximin
   - try to limit  Fentanyl  and d/c her propofol at this point
   .
   # EtoH withdrawal:
   - Ativan drip to max 8mg/hr now , will wean today
   - now off of propofol completely
   - basal Fentanyl with boluses as needed /  weaning slowly as tolerates
   - continue on haldol 2mg q8h standing, monitor QTC
   - continue mvt/thiamine/folate
   - social work input appreciated, will continue to follow
   .
   #Stool changes: stools more odorous and discolored today. [**Month (only) 11**] just
   simply be lactulose effects and hyperbilirubinemia vs.  recent
   antibiotics with ceftriaxone.
   - will send off C.difficile
   .
   #Electrolyte abnormalities: Chronic issue even as outpatient as she has
   need for Mg and K repletion at home. She has been having low Phos, Mg,
   K  in setting of worse liver failure
   --Will continue to check [**Hospital1 **] lytes and replete as needed
   .
   # Anemia:
   Pt with baseline anemia, also h/o BRBPR at home though none here. Had
   some oral trauma in setting of intubation causing some additional blood
   loss.
   - active type and screen, transfuse hct>21 or active bleeding
   - check Hcts daily
   - continue PPI
   - stool guaiacs
   .
   # Ventilation:
   Overbreathing slightly but will allow given metabolic acidosis.  CXRs
   have been  clear. She had been intubated for airway protection / AMS.
   - Did not tolerate PSV well so will continue to rest on A/C for today
   to maintain safe airway given extreme AMS and encephalopathy.
   .
   # Increased secretions/ recent fevers:  No current leukocytosis or
   fevers and lactate elevation has now corrected so may not be any clear
   infection.  Intubation with AMS on admission so need to be weary of
   aspiration PNAs and VAP.
   -CIS, low threshold to cover with Abx / holding off for now
   -f/up sputum, blood cultures
   -follow CXRs for interval changes
   .
   # Conjunctivitis: Eyes with bilateral yellowish-green thick secretions
   along conjunctivae when admitted.  Much improved eye exam with no
   crusting today.
   -erythromycin eye ointment QID ( day 4 of 7 )

* Cardiovascular: The patient's blood pressure is 112/63 mmHg, and her heart rate is 88 beats per minute.
* Neurological: The patient is sedated and has encephalopathy, with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 11.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has ascites, and her bilirubin level is increasing. She is receiving lactulose and rifaximin for hepatic encephalopathy.
* Infection: The patient has a C. difficile infection, which was sent off for confirmation. She is also at risk for aspiration pneumonia and ventilator-associated pneumonia.
* Electrolyte abnormalities: The patient has chronic electrolyte abnormalities, including hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia.
* Hematology: The patient has anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 7.4 g/dL.
* Endocrine: The patient has adrenal insufficiency, with a cortisol level of <0.01 ng/mL.
* Liver function: The patient's liver function is deteriorating, with a discriminant function of 63 and a bilirubin level of 24.3 mg/dL.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's immunocompromised state and the presence of C. difficile infection, she is at risk for developing sepsis.
2. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient's intubation and encephalopathy put her at risk for aspiration pneumonia.
3. Ventilator-associated pneumonia: The patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation increases her risk for developing ventilator-associated pneumonia.
4. Liver failure: The patient's liver function is deteriorating, and she is at risk for developing liver failure.
5. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's chronic electrolyte abnormalities, including hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia, can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and muscle weakness.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia can lead to fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased exercise tolerance.
7. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency can lead to fatigue, weakness, and low blood pressure.
8. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's hepatic encephalopathy can lead to confusion, disorientation, and altered mental status.

In summary, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple comorbidities, including liver failure, electrolyte abnormalities, anemia, and adrenal insufficiency. She is at risk for developing various medical complications, including sepsis, aspiration pneumonia, ventilator-associated pneumonia, liver failure, electrolyte imbalance, anemia, adrenal insufficiency, and hepatic encephalopathy.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 42-year-old female with alcoholic hepatitis, altered mental status, elevated lactate levels, and recent fevers. She is currently intubated and sedated in the ICU.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3°C, heart rate of 88 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 112/63 mmHg. Her respiratory support includes an endotracheal tube and mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate levels, and troponin-T levels, indicating possible sepsis and cardiac injury. Her liver enzymes, including aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT), are elevated, suggesting liver damage.

The patient has a history of C. difficile infection and is at risk for developing nosocomial infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI).

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate levels and white blood cell count suggest possible sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure if not treated promptly.
2. Cardiac injury: The patient's elevated troponin-T levels indicate possible cardiac injury, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and even death.
3. Liver failure: The patient's elevated liver enzymes and liver damage can lead to liver failure, which can cause coagulopathy, encephalopathy, and death.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory support is critical, and she is at risk for developing respiratory failure if her mechanical ventilation is not properly managed.
5. Infection: The patient is at risk for developing nosocomial infections, such as VAP and CLABSI, which can lead to sepsis, organ dysfunction, and death.
6. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid balance is critical, and she is at risk for developing fluid overload if her fluid intake is not properly managed.
7. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels, including potassium, magnesium, and phosphorus, are critical, and she is at risk for developing electrolyte imbalances if not properly managed.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for developing various medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

   Assessment and Plan:
   42 year old female with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis who presented
   with acute fulminant hepatic failure with multiple electrolyte
   abnormalities, confusion, fevers, & lactate elevation being treated for
   alcoholic hepatitis and ETOH withdrawal
   .
   #Alcoholic hepatitis:
   Ultrasound with poor study but patent vasculature and no overt ascites
   noted.  Discriminate function is 63 on admit.  Estimated mortality
   given her degree of elevation in the presence of encephalopathy is on
   the order of 45%.  Bilirubin continues to climb.
   - continue steroids d5 today
   - continue  pentoxiphylline
   - continue tube feeds via OGT
   - trend LFTs, synthetic function daily
   - f/up liver recs, appreciate input
   .
   # Encephalopathy: Most consistent with hepatic encephalopathy and EtoH
   withdrawal. Recent CT head without evidence of any bleeding.
   - continue lactulose and rifaximin
   - try to limit  Fentanyl, continue taper down ativan
   .
   # EtoH withdrawal:
   - Ativan drip to max 8mg/hr now , will wean today down to 6mg/hr today
   - basal Fentanyl with boluses as needed /  weaning slowly as tolerates
   - continue on haldol 2mg q8h standing, monitor QTC (ok today)
   - continue mvt/thiamine/folate
   - social work input appreciated, will continue to follow
   .
   #Stool changes/distended abdomen: stools more odorous and discolored
   today. [**Month (only) 11**] just simply be lactulose effects and hyperbilirubinemia vs.
   recent antibiotics with ceftriaxone.
   - will send off C.difficile
   - f/u KUB
   .
   #Electrolyte abnormalities: Chronic issue even as outpatient as she has
   need for Mg and K repletion at home. She has been having low Phos, Mg,
   K  in setting of worse liver failure
   --Will continue to check [**Hospital1 **] lytes and replete as needed
   .
   # Anemia:
   Pt with baseline anemia, also h/o BRBPR at home though none here. Had
   some oral trauma in setting of intubation causing some additional blood
   loss.
   - active type and screen, transfuse hct>21 or active bleeding
   - check Hcts daily
   - continue PPI
   - stool guaiacs
   .
   # Ventilation: Still remains intubated.
   Unable to tolerate SBT [**3-10**] tachypnea
 also may be element of fluid
   overload.  CXRs have been  clear. She had been intubated for airway
   protection / AMS.
   - Did not tolerate PSV well so will continue to rest on A/C for today
   to maintain safe airway given extreme AMS and encephalopathy.
   - Keep I/Os with goal 1L negative. Will give dose of 20 IV lasix now,
   recheck in PM
   .
   # Increased secretions/ recent fevers:  No current leukocytosis or
   fevers and lactate elevation has now corrected so may not be any clear
   infection.  Intubation with AMS on admission so need to be weary of
   aspiration PNAs and VAP.
   -CIS, low threshold to cover with Abx / holding off for now
   -f/up sputum, blood cultures
   -follow CXRs for interval changes
   .
   # Conjunctivitis: Eyes with bilateral yellowish-green thick secretions
   along conjunctivae when admitted.  Much improved eye exam with no
   crusting today.
   -erythromycin eye ointment QID ( day 5 of 7 )
   -continue to monitor ; improving
   .
   # Vaginal discharge: Patient with malodorous discharge from below. Was
   started on vaginal flagyl overnight. Patient with history of STDs
   - continue vaginal flagyl
   - consider STD testing/f/u when mental status improved
   - social work when mental status improved
   # Peripheral neuropathy
   - holding gabapentin for now given sedated
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:  OG tube feeds at goal
   Glycemic Control:   continue FSG checks, Humalog PRN for now
   Lines:
   - order for PICC placement
   16 Gauge - [**2139-5-21**] 09:50 AM
   20 Gauge - [**2139-5-22**] 09:47 AM
   18 Gauge - [**2139-5-22**] 09:54 AM
   Arterial Line - [**2139-5-22**] 08:25 PM

   Stress ulcer:  PPI
   VAP:  VAP bundle
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: Sister. Privacy [**Name2 (NI) 421**] against her boyfriend
   (h/o abuse?) so he cannot be let in to see her

   - continue steroids d5 today
   - continue  pentoxiphylline
   - continue tube feeds via OGT
   - trend LFTs, synthetic function daily
   - f/up liver recs, appreciate input
   .
   # Encephalopathy: Most consistent with hepatic encephalopathy and EtoH
   withdrawal. Recent CT head without evidence of any bleeding.
   - continue lactulose and rifaximin
   - try to limit  Fentanyl, continue taper down ativan
   .
   # EtoH withdrawal:
   - Ativan drip to max 8mg/hr now , will wean today down to 6mg/hr today
   - basal Fentanyl with boluses as needed /  weaning slowly as tolerates
   - continue on haldol 2mg q8h standing, monitor QTC (ok today)
   - continue mvt/thiamine/folate
   - social work input appreciated, will continue to follow
   .
   #Stool changes/distended abdomen: stools more odorous and discolored
   today. [**Month (only) 11**] just simply be lactulose effects and hyperbilirubinemia vs.
   recent antibiotics with ceftriaxone.
   - will send off C.difficile
   - f/u KUB
   .
   #Electrolyte abnormalities: Chronic issue even as outpatient as she has
   need for Mg and K repletion at home. She has been having low Phos, Mg,
   K  in setting of worse liver failure
   --Will continue to check [**Hospital1 **] lytes and replete as needed
   .
   # Anemia:
   Pt with baseline anemia, also h/o BRBPR at home though none here. Had
   some oral trauma in setting of intubation causing some additional blood
   loss.
   - active type and screen, transfuse hct>21 or active bleeding
   - check Hcts daily
   - continue PPI
   - stool guaiacs
   .
   # Ventilation: Still remains intubated.
   Unable to tolerate SBT [**3-10**] tachypnea
 also may be element of fluid
   overload.  CXRs have been  clear. She had been intubated for airway
   protection / AMS.
   - Did not tolerate PSV well so will continue to rest on A/C for today
   to maintain safe airway given extreme AMS and encephalopathy.
   - Keep I/Os with goal 1L negative. Will give dose of 20 IV lasix now,
   recheck in PM
   .
   # Increased secretions/ recent fevers:  No current leukocytosis or
   fevers and lactate elevation has now corrected so may not be any clear
   infection.  Intubation with AMS on admission so need to be weary of
   aspiration PNAs and VAP.
   -CIS, low threshold to cover with Abx / holding off for now
   -f/up sputum, blood cultures
   -follow CXRs for interval changes
   .

   along conjunctivae when admitted.  Much improved eye exam with no
   crusting today.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 42-year-old female with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis, acute fulminant hepatic failure, and multiple electrolyte abnormalities.
* She is intubated and sedated due to encephalopathy and ethanol withdrawal.
* She has elevated bilirubin levels, liver function tests (LFTs) are abnormal, and synthetic function is impaired.
* She has a history of anemia, and her hemoglobin (Hb) level is 9.9 g/dL.
* She has a distended abdomen with odorous and discolored stools, which may be due to lactulose effects, hyperbilirubinemia, or C. difficile infection.
* She has electrolyte abnormalities, including hypernatremia, hypokalemia, and hypophosphatemia.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Infection:** The patient has a high risk of developing infections, particularly C. difficile-associated diarrhea, given her history of antibiotic use and liver dysfunction.
2. **Hepatic Encephalopathy:** The patient's encephalopathy may worsen, leading to increased risk of bleeding, respiratory failure, and death.
3. **Ethanol Withdrawal:** The patient's ethanol withdrawal symptoms may worsen, leading to increased risk of seizures, arrhythmias, and cardiovascular instability.
4. **Anemia:** The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to increased risk of bleeding, cardiovascular instability, and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
5. **Electrolyte Imbalance:** The patient's electrolyte imbalance may worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and neurological symptoms.
6. **Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP):** The patient is at high risk of developing VAP due to her intubation and prolonged mechanical ventilation.
7. **Bloodstream Infection:** The patient is at high risk of developing bloodstream infections due to her central venous catheters and peripheral IV lines.
8. **Catheter-Related Bloodstream Infection (CR-BSI):** The patient is at high risk of developing CR-BSI due to her multiple central venous catheters and peripheral IV lines.

**Plan:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's liver function, electrolyte levels, and hemoglobin levels.
* Continue to manage the patient's encephalopathy and ethanol withdrawal symptoms.
* Consider sending off C. difficile toxin A and B tests and stool cultures to rule out C. difficile infection.
* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as needed.
* Consider placing a percutaneous central venous catheter (PICC) to improve access for medications and laboratory tests.
* Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust medications as needed.
* Consider performing a thorough skin examination to rule out any signs of sepsis or infection.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, I summarize the following information:

1. The patient is a 42-year-old female with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis who presented with acute fulminant hepatic failure, multiple electrolyte abnormalities, confusion, fevers, and lactate elevation.
2. The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are elevated, with a bilirubin level of 38 mg/dL, and her synthetic function is impaired.
3. The patient has encephalopathy, which is likely due to hepatic encephalopathy and ETOH withdrawal.
4. The patient's electrolyte abnormalities include hypernatremia, hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia, and hypophosphatemia.
5. The patient has anemia, which is likely due to chronic blood loss and gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. The patient remains intubated and ventilated due to acute respiratory failure and encephalopathy.
7. The patient has conjunctivitis, which has improved with treatment, and vaginal discharge, which is being treated with vaginal flagyl.
8. The patient has a history of STDs and is being considered for STD testing when her mental status improves.
9. The patient has peripheral neuropathy, which is being managed with gabapentin.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Increased risk of bleeding due to coagulopathy and thrombocytopenia.
2. Development of sepsis or septic shock due to the patient's immunocompromised state and the presence of a central line.
3. Respiratory failure due to continued need for mechanical ventilation and the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
4. Worsening of encephalopathy and liver failure, leading to further impairment of synthetic function and increased risk of death.
5. Development of renal failure due to the patient's electrolyte abnormalities and the use of nephrotoxic medications.
6. Increased risk of infections, including pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and sepsis, due to the patient's immunocompromised state and the presence of indwelling catheters.
7. Development of gastrointestinal bleeding due to the patient's anemia and the use of anticoagulant medications.
8. Worsening of peripheral neuropathy, leading to further impairment of the patient's quality of life.
9. Development of other complications, such as pancreatitis, due to the patient's liver failure and the use of medications such as propofol.

Based on the patient's condition, I recommend the following:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's liver function tests and synthetic function daily.
2. Adjust the patient's electrolyte levels as needed to prevent further complications.
3. Continue to manage the patient's encephalopathy with lactulose and rifaximin.
4. Wean the patient off sedation and pain medication as tolerated.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as needed.
6. Consider placement of a central line for administration of medications and fluids.
7. Monitor the patient's blood counts and adjust anticoagulant medications as needed.
8. Consider consultation with a gastroenterologist or transplant specialist for further management of the patient's liver failure.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust treatment plans as needed to address any changes in her condition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 42-year-old female with a history of ethanol (ETOH) abuse, presenting with ETOH hepatitis, withdrawal symptoms, and intubation for airway protection. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 93 bpm, and blood pressure of 107/58 mmHg.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. ETOH hepatitis: The patient is receiving treatment with prednisone, pentoxyphiline, and lactulose. Her liver function tests (LFTs) are trending, and she is at risk for liver failure.
2. ETOH withdrawal: The patient is experiencing withdrawal symptoms, including tachycardia, and is being treated with haloperidol and lorazepam. She is at risk for seizures and other withdrawal-related complications.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated for airway protection, but is now experiencing tachypnea on positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) and pressure support ventilation (PSV). She may require further respiratory support, such as non-invasive ventilation or mechanical ventilation.
4. Electrolyte abnormalities: The patient has hypernatremia, which is being treated with normal saline (NS). She also has hypokalemia, which is being treated with potassium supplements.
5. Conjunctivitis: The patient has conjunctivitis, which is being treated with erythromycin.
6. FEN (fetal growth restriction): The patient is receiving tube feeds at goal, but may require further nutrition support.
7. ICU care: The patient is receiving prophylactic antibiotics, stress ulcer prophylaxis, and venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis. She is also receiving daily wake-up calls, mouth care, and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) prophylaxis.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Liver failure: The patient's ETOH hepatitis may progress to liver failure, which can be life-threatening.
2. Seizures: The patient's ETOH withdrawal symptoms may lead to seizures, which can be life-threatening.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, requiring further respiratory support or mechanical ventilation.
4. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's electrolyte abnormalities may worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias or other complications.
5. Infection: The patient's conjunctivitis may spread to other parts of the body, leading to a serious infection.
6. Malnutrition: The patient's malnutrition may worsen, leading to further complications.
7. VTE: The patient's VTE prophylaxis may be inadequate, leading to a life-threatening pulmonary embolism.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management of her various medical complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 42-year-old female with a history of ethanol (ETOH) abuse, presenting with ETOH hepatitis and withdrawal symptoms requiring intubation for management. She is currently receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL, PEEP of 5 cmH2O, and FiO2 of 40%. Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 93 bpm, blood pressure of 107/58 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute. She has a history of poor dentition and is receiving tube feeds at goal.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 10.6 K/uL, hemoglobin of 7.4 g/dL, and platelet count of 146 K/uL. Her liver function tests are elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) of 129 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) of 41 IU/L. Her electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with a sodium level of 146 mEq/L and a potassium level of 3.6 mEq/L.

The patient's medical plan includes the continuation of prednisone and pentoxyphiline for ETOH hepatitis, as well as lactulose tid. She is also receiving haloperidol and lorazepam for ETOH withdrawal. Her respiratory support plan includes a trial of pressure support ventilation (PSV) as tolerated, and her nutritional plan includes tube feeds at goal.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and she is at risk of developing respiratory failure if her ventilation settings are not optimized.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and abnormal liver function tests may indicate an underlying infection, which could progress to sepsis if not treated promptly.
3. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, and she is at risk of developing electrolyte imbalances if not closely monitored and managed.
4. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's liver function tests are elevated, and she is at risk of developing hepatic encephalopathy if her liver function does not improve.
5. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory status and abnormal chest x-ray findings may indicate the presence of pneumonia, which could worsen her respiratory status and overall condition.
6. DVT: The patient's immobility and central venous catheters may increase her risk of developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which could lead to pulmonary embolism if not treated promptly.
7. VAP: The patient's intubation and respiratory support may increase her risk of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), which could worsen her respiratory status and overall condition.

   Assessment and Plan
   42 year old female with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis who presented
   with acute fulminant hepatic failure with multiple electrolyte
   abnormalities, confusion, fevers, & lactate elevation being treated for
   alcoholic hepatitis and ETOH withdrawal, still intubated for airway
   protection.
   .
   #Alcoholic hepatitis:
   Ultrasound with poor study but patent vasculature and no overt ascites
   noted.  Discriminate function is 63 on admit.  Estimated mortality
   given her degree of elevation in the presence of encephalopathy is on
   the order of 45%.  Bilirubin continues to elevated at 37.8 now .
   - discontinued steroids today as no improvement in bili on this
   - continue  pentoxiphylline
   - continue daily lactulose and rifaxamin as below
   - continue mvt/thiamine/folate
   - continue tube feeds via OGT
   - trend LFTs, synthetic function daily
   - f/up liver recs, appreciate input
   .
   # Encephalopathy: Most consistent with hepatic encephalopathy and EtoH
   withdrawal. Recent CT head without evidence of any bleeding. Ativan
   tapered down to 6 overnight
   - continue lactulose and rifaxamin
   - try to limit  Fentanyl, continue taper down ativan as tolerates,
   taper at 4 today
   .
   # EtoH withdrawal:
   - Ativan drip tapering as she tolerates ( down from max 8mg/hr to
   6mg/hr now , trial of 4mg/hr today)
   - basal Fentanyl with boluses as needed /  weaning slowly as tolerates
   (75 today)
   - continue on haldol 2mg q8h standing, monitor QTC w/EKG
   - continue mvi/thiamine/folate
   - social work input appreciated, will continue to follow
   .
   # Ventilation: Still remains intubated. [**Month (only) 11**] be secondary to new VAP by
   CXR, increased secretions
   Unable to tolerate SBT [**3-10**] tachypnea
 also may be element of fluid
   overload. She had been intubated for airway protection / AMS.
   - Did not tolerate PSV well so will continue to rest on A/C for today
   to maintain safe airway given extreme AMS and encephalopathy.
   - Keep I/Os with goal -1L negative
 gentle diuresis with PRN 20 IV
   lasix as needed
   - maintaine UOP >40cc/hr
   . .
   # Increased secretions/ recent fevers:  No current leukocytosis but Tm
   to 100.5F and questionable infiltrate overnight on CXR at RLL.
   Lactate elevation has now corrected , but this was likely more related
   to ALF.  Intubation with AMS on admission so need to be weary of
   aspiration PNAs and VAP.  Opted to start therapy overnight as below.
   -continue on Vanco/Cef/Cipro for VAP coverage for now  (day [**3-16**])
   -CIS
   -f/up sputum, blood cultures
   -follow CXRs for interval changes
   #Stool changes/distended abdomen: stools more odorous and discolored
   today. [**Month (only) 11**] just simply be lactulose effects and hyperbilirubinemia vs.
   recent antibiotics with ceftriaxone. Overnight C.difficile  was
   negative. KUB with fluid and air in colon.
   .
   #Electrolyte abnormalities: Chronic issue even as outpatient as she has
   need for Mg and K repletion at home. She has been having low Phos, Mg,
   K  in setting of worse liver failure. Also with hypernatremia with free
   water repletion
   --Will continue to check [**Hospital1 **] lytes and replete as needed
   - continue free water flushes, but decrease if Na continues to be
   improved
   .
   # Anemia:
   Pt with baseline anemia, also h/o BRBPR at home though none here. Had
   some oral trauma in setting of intubation causing some additional blood
   loss.  HCt stable at 26-28 range for several days now.
   - active type and screen, transfuse hct>21 or active bleeding
   - check Hcts daily
   - continue PPI
   - stool guaiacs
   .
   # Conjunctivitis: Eyes with bilateral yellowish-green thick secretions
   along conjunctivae when admitted.  Much improved eye exam with no
   crusting today.
   -erythromycin eye ointment QID ( day 6 of 7 today  )
   -continue to monitor ; improving
   .
   # Vaginal discharge: Patient with malodorous discharge from below. Was
   started on vaginal flagyl overnight. Patient with history of STDs
   - continue vaginal flagyl
   - send urine for chlamydia/gonorrhea, HCV, RPR
   - consider STD testing/f/u when mental status improved
   - social work when mental status improved
   # Peripheral neuropathy
   - holding gabapentin for now given sedated

 also may be element of fluid

Summary:

The patient is a 42-year-old female with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis who presented with acute fulminant hepatic failure, altered mental status, and fevers. She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation due to airway protection and encephalopathy. The patient has multiple electrolyte abnormalities, including hypernatremia, hypokalemia, and hypophosphatemia, which are being managed with electrolyte replacement and diuresis. She also has anemia, which is being monitored and managed with blood transfusions as needed.

The patient has a variety of medical conditions, including alcoholic hepatitis, encephalopathy, and ETOH withdrawal, which are being managed with medications such as lactulose, rifaximin, and pentoxiphylline. She also has a history of vaginal discharge, which is being treated with vaginal flagyl, and conjunctivitis, which is being treated with erythromycin eye ointment.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's CXR shows a possible infiltrate at the right lower lobe, which may indicate VAP.
2. Sepsis: The patient's temperature is elevated, and she has a history of fevers, which may indicate sepsis.
3. Encephalopathy: The patient's altered mental status and elevated bilirubin levels may indicate encephalopathy, which is a complication of liver failure.
4. Electrolyte abnormalities: The patient's hypernatremia, hypokalemia, and hypophosphatemia may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other complications.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may lead to fatigue, shortness of breath, and other complications.
6. Infections: The patient's history of vaginal discharge and conjunctivitis may indicate underlying infections.
7. Liver failure: The patient's acute fulminant hepatic failure may lead to liver failure and death if not managed properly.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, including temperature, blood pressure, and oxygen saturation.
2. Continue to manage the patient's electrolyte abnormalities with electrolyte replacement and diuresis.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and transfuse blood as needed.
4. Continue to manage the patient's VAP with antibiotics and other treatments.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's encephalopathy and adjust medications as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's liver function and adjust medications as needed.
7. Consider consulting with a specialist, such as a gastroenterologist or a pulmonologist, to help manage the patient's medical conditions.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-inch tall, 94.2 kg individual who is intubated and sedated in the ICU. The patient has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, sedatives, and analgesics. 

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.8°C, heart rate of 105 bpm, blood pressure of 104/54 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient's respiratory support includes a CPAP/PSV ventilator with a set tidal volume of 450 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 23 cmH2O, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 8 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 11.3 K/uL, hemoglobin of 8.1 g/dL, and platelet count of 159 K/uL. The patient's renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 0.8 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 21 mEq/L. The patient's liver function tests are mildly elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 121 U/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 36 U/L.

The patient has a history of pancreatitis, with a pancreatic amylase level of 93 U/L and a lipase level of 93 U/L. The patient's lactic acid level is 1.5 mmol/L, indicating possible tissue hypoperfusion.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's pancreatitis and elevated white blood cell count increase the risk of sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory support is complex, and the risk of respiratory failure is high.
3. Renal failure: The patient's impaired renal function and elevated BUN level increase the risk of renal failure.
4. Hepatic failure: The patient's mildly elevated liver function tests and history of pancreatitis increase the risk of hepatic failure.
5. Pneumonia: The patient's intubation and prolonged hospitalization increase the risk of developing pneumonia.
6. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's immobility and history of pancreatitis increase the risk of developing DVT.
7. Stress ulcer: The patient's critical illness and prolonged hospitalization increase the risk of developing stress ulcer.
8. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's prolonged intubation increases the risk of developing VAP.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust their treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   42 year old female with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis who presented
   with acute fulminant hepatic failure with multiple electrolyte
   abnormalities, confusion, fevers, & lactate elevation being treated for
   alcoholic hepatitis and ETOH withdrawal
   .
   #Alcoholic hepatitis:
   Ultrasound with poor study but patent vasculature and no overt ascites
   noted.  Discriminate function is 63 on admit.  Estimated mortality
   given her degree of elevation in the presence of encephalopathy is on
   the order of 45%.  Bilirubin continues to climb.
   - continue steroids d5 today
   - continue  pentoxiphylline
   - continue tube feeds via OGT
   - trend LFTs, synthetic function daily
   - f/up liver recs, appreciate input
   .
   # Encephalopathy: Most consistent with hepatic encephalopathy and EtoH
   withdrawal. Recent CT head without evidence of any bleeding.
   - continue lactulose and rifaximin
   - try to limit  Fentanyl, continue taper down ativan
   .
   # EtoH withdrawal:
   - Ativan drip to max 8mg/hr now , will wean today down to 6mg/hr today
   - basal Fentanyl with boluses as needed /  weaning slowly as tolerates
   - continue on haldol 2mg q8h standing, monitor QTC (ok today)
   - continue mvt/thiamine/folate
   - social work input appreciated, will continue to follow
   .
   #Stool changes/distended abdomen: stools more odorous and discolored
   today. [**Month (only) 11**] just simply be lactulose effects and hyperbilirubinemia vs.
   recent antibiotics with ceftriaxone. Overnight C.difficile  was
   negative
   - f/u KUB
   .
   #Electrolyte abnormalities: Chronic issue even as outpatient as she has
   need for Mg and K repletion at home. She has been having low Phos, Mg,
   K  in setting of worse liver failure
   --Will continue to check [**Hospital1 **] lytes and replete as needed
   .
   # Anemia:
   Pt with baseline anemia, also h/o BRBPR at home though none here. Had
   some oral trauma in setting of intubation causing some additional blood
   loss.
   - active type and screen, transfuse hct>21 or active bleeding
   - check Hcts daily
   - continue PPI
   - stool guaiacs
   .
   # Ventilation: Still remains intubated.
   Unable to tolerate SBT [**3-10**] tachypnea
 also may be element of fluid
   overload.  CXRs have been  clear. She had been intubated for airway
   protection / AMS.
   - Did not tolerate PSV well so will continue to rest on A/C for today
   to maintain safe airway given extreme AMS and encephalopathy.
   - Keep I/Os with goal 1L negative. Will give dose of 20 IV lasix now,
   recheck in PM
   .
   # Increased secretions/ recent fevers:  No current leukocytosis or
   fevers and lactate elevation has now corrected so may not be any clear
   infection.  Intubation with AMS on admission so need to be weary of
   aspiration PNAs and VAP.
   -CIS, low threshold to cover with Abx / holding off for now
   -f/up sputum, blood cultures
   -follow CXRs for interval changes
   .
   # Conjunctivitis: Eyes with bilateral yellowish-green thick secretions
   along conjunctivae when admitted.  Much improved eye exam with no
   crusting today.
   -erythromycin eye ointment QID ( day 5 of 7 )
   -continue to monitor ; improving
   .
   # Vaginal discharge: Patient with malodorous discharge from below. Was
   started on vaginal flagyl overnight. Patient with history of STDs
   - continue vaginal flagyl
   - consider STD testing/f/u when mental status improved
   - social work when mental status improved
   # Peripheral neuropathy
   - holding gabapentin for now given sedated
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Fibersource HN (Full) - [**2139-5-25**] 03:57 AM 40 mL/hour

   - check Hcts daily
   - continue PPI
   - stool guaiacs
   .

   Unable to tolerate SBT [**3-10**] tachypnea
 also may be element of fluid
   overload.  CXRs have been  clear. She had been intubated for airway
   protection / AMS.
   - Did not tolerate PSV well so will continue to rest on A/C for today
   to maintain safe airway given extreme AMS and encephalopathy.
   - Keep I/Os with goal 1L negative. Will give dose of 20 IV lasix now,
   recheck in PM
   .
   # Increased secretions/ recent fevers:  No current leukocytosis or
   fevers and lactate elevation has now corrected so may not be any clear
   infection.  Intubation with AMS on admission so need to be weary of
   aspiration PNAs and VAP.
   -CIS, low threshold to cover with Abx / holding off for now
   -f/up sputum, blood cultures
   -follow CXRs for interval changes
   .
   # Conjunctivitis: Eyes with bilateral yellowish-green thick secretions
   along conjunctivae when admitted.  Much improved eye exam with no
   crusting today.
   -erythromycin eye ointment QID ( day 5 of 7 )
   -continue to monitor ; improving
   .
   # Vaginal discharge: Patient with malodorous discharge from below. Was
   started on vaginal flagyl overnight. Patient with history of STDs
   - continue vaginal flagyl
   - consider STD testing/f/u when mental status improved
   - social work when mental status improved
   # Peripheral neuropathy
   - holding gabapentin for now given sedated

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 42-year-old female with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis who presented with acute fulminant hepatic failure, altered mental status (AMS), and suspected pneumonia. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 100.5°F (38.1°C)
* Heart rate: 105 bpm (92-120 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 104/54 mmHg (68-92 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 26 breaths per minute (20-32 breaths per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 97%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC count: 11.3 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 8.1 g/dL
* Platelet count: 159 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.4 mg/dL
* Bilirubin: 37.8 mg/dL
* Alkaline phosphatase: 289 IU/L
* Alanine aminotransferase (ALT): 36 IU/L
* Aspartate aminotransferase (AST): 121 IU/L
* Lactic acid: 1.5 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.5 g/dL
* Calcium: 8.6 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.4 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Intubated and sedated
* Bilateral mild crackles in the lungs
* Diffuse distension of the abdomen
* Normoactive bowel sounds
* Pitting edema of the extremities

The patient's medications include:

* Vancomycin
* Ciprofloxacin
* Cefepime
* Lorazepam (Ativan)
* Fentanyl (Concentrate)
* Furosemide (Lasix)
* Pantoprazole (Protonix)
* Heparin sodium (Prophylaxis)
* Gabapentin (held due to sedation)

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Pneumonia (suspected)
* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
* Aspiration pneumonia
* Hepatic encephalopathy
* Ethanol withdrawal
* Electrolyte imbalances (hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypomagnesemia)
* Anemia
* Thrombocytopenia
* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* Organ failure (hepatic, renal, and respiratory)

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue steroids and pentoxifylline for alcoholic hepatitis
* Continue lactulose and rifaximin for encephalopathy
* Wean Fentanyl and Ativan as tolerated
* Continue tube feeds and monitor for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding
* Monitor for signs of infection and adjust antibiotics as necessary
* Continue prophylactic antibiotics for VAP
* Monitor for signs of respiratory failure and adjust ventilation as necessary
* Continue to monitor electrolyte levels and replete as necessary
* Continue to monitor hemoglobin and platelet counts and transfuse as necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 42-year-old female with a history of ethanol abuse, who presented with ethanol hepatitis and is now experiencing withdrawal symptoms. She is intubated for airway protection and is being treated for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) with antibiotics. She has developed fever, increased secretions, and bibasilar infiltrates, which are presumed to be caused by VAP. She is also experiencing electrolyte abnormalities, including hypernatremia, and is being treated with free water boluses.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 100.4°F, heart rate of 110 bpm, and blood pressure of 110/61 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 28 breaths per minute, and she is receiving oxygen therapy via an endotracheal tube. Her oxygen saturation is 95%.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, and elevated liver enzymes. Her blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels are normal. Her electrolyte levels are abnormal, with hypernatremia and hypokalemia.

The patient's imaging studies show a developing right lower lobe infiltrate on chest X-ray.

Potential medical complications:

1. VAP: The patient's symptoms of fever, increased secretions, and bibasilar infiltrates are consistent with VAP. If left untreated, VAP can lead to respiratory failure, septic shock, and death.
2. Ethanol withdrawal: The patient's symptoms of tachycardia, hypertension, and tremors are consistent with ethanol withdrawal. If left untreated, ethanol withdrawal can lead to seizures, hallucinations, and death.
3. Electrolyte abnormalities: The patient's hypernatremia and hypokalemia can lead to muscle weakness, cardiac arrhythmias, and respiratory failure if left untreated.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and hypoxemia can lead to respiratory failure if left untreated.
5. Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count can indicate the presence of sepsis. If left untreated, sepsis can lead to organ failure and death.
6. Liver failure: The patient's ethanol hepatitis can lead to liver failure if left untreated. Liver failure can lead to coagulopathy, ascites, and death.
7. Infection: The patient's presence of sputum culture pending can indicate the presence of an infection. If left untreated, infection can lead to sepsis, organ failure, and death.

Based on the patient's condition, it is recommended that she continue to receive antibiotics for VAP, and that her electrolyte levels be closely monitored and treated as necessary. She should also be monitored for signs of ethanol withdrawal and treated with medications as necessary. Additionally, her respiratory status should be closely monitored, and she should be considered for extubation if her respiratory status improves.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 42-year-old female with a history of ethanol (ETOH) abuse, who presents with ETOH hepatitis and withdrawal symptoms. The patient is currently intubated for airway protection and is being managed for respiratory failure.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 100.4°F, heart rate of 110 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 110/61 mmHg. The patient's respiratory rate is 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 95%.

The patient has a developing right lower lobe (RLL) infiltrate on the chest X-ray (CXR), and a persistent left lower lobe (LLL) infiltrate. The patient's white blood cell count (WBC) is elevated at 11.3 K/uL, and the patient's platelet count (Plt) is low at 135 K/uL.

The patient is being managed with antibiotics, including vancomycin, cefepime, and ciprofloxacin, for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient is also receiving fentanyl and lorazepam for pain and sedation, respectively.

The patient has electrolyte abnormalities, including hypernatremia, and is receiving free water boluses to correct this. The patient's blood glucose level is elevated at 126 mg/dL, and the patient is being managed with a regular insulin sliding scale for glycemic control.

The patient has a number of potential medical complications that could arise, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently intubated, and the CXR shows a developing RLL infiltrate. The patient may require further respiratory support, such as mechanical ventilation or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Sepsis: The patient has a low platelet count and elevated WBC count, which could indicate sepsis. The patient may require further antibiotics and supportive care.
3. Liver failure: The patient has ETOH hepatitis, which could lead to liver failure. The patient may require further management with medications such as lactulose and pentoxyphiline.
4. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient has hypernatremia, which could lead to further electrolyte imbalances. The patient may require further electrolyte replacement and monitoring.
5. Infection: The patient has a developing RLL infiltrate on the CXR, which could indicate an infection. The patient may require further antibiotics and supportive care.

In conclusion, the patient is critically ill and requires ongoing monitoring and management for a number of potential medical complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 42-year-old female with a history of ethanol (ETOH) abuse, who was admitted to the ICU for management of ethanol hepatitis and withdrawal, requiring intubation for airway protection due to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient is currently receiving antibiotics for VAP, and has been experiencing fever, increased secretions, and bibasilar infiltrates. The patient's laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes, and imaging studies reveal developing right lower lobe (RLL) infiltrate and persistent left lower lobe (LLL) infiltrate.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is tenuous, with a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute and a ratio of 311, indicating a high risk of respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever, increased secretions, and bibasilar infiltrates suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
3. Liver Failure: The patient's ethanol hepatitis may progress to liver failure, which can lead to coagulopathy, encephalopathy, and increased risk of infections.
4. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, with hypernatremia and hypokalemia, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and muscle weakness.
5. VAP-Related Complications: The patient's VAP may lead to respiratory failure, sepsis, and multi-organ dysfunction.
6. Withdrawal Syndrome: The patient's ethanol withdrawal may lead to seizures, hallucinations, and other withdrawal symptoms.
7. Infection: The patient's compromised immune system and prolonged hospitalization increase the risk of developing hospital-acquired infections.
8. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension may lead to cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics for VAP and monitor for signs of sepsis.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider adjusting ventilator settings or intubation as needed.
3. Continue to manage the patient's ethanol withdrawal symptoms with medications and monitor for signs of withdrawal syndrome.
4. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels closely and adjust as needed to prevent electrolyte imbalance.
5. Consider adjusting the patient's medications to prevent and treat potential complications, such as stress ulcer prophylaxis and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis.
6. Monitor the patient's liver function tests and consider adjusting medications to prevent and treat liver failure.
7. Consider consulting with a specialist, such as a pulmonologist or gastroenterologist, for further management of the patient's respiratory and liver issues.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 42-year-old female who has been admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with ethanol (ETOH) abuse, ETOH hepatitis, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient has been receiving antibiotics for VAP and has developed hypernatremia, which has been treated with free water boluses.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 100.5°F (38.1°C)
* Heart rate: 110 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 110/61 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 28 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 95%
* SpO2: 95%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Well-nourished appearance
* Endotracheal tube in place
* Right lower extremity edema: 1+
* Left lower extremity edema: 1+
* Soft, non-tender abdomen
* Diminished breath sounds in the bases of the lungs

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 11.3-10.1 K/uL
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 7.4 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 159-135 K/uL
* Creatinine (Cr): 0.4-0.8 mg/dL
* Total bilirubin (Tbil): 23-25.1 mg/dL
* Alanine aminotransferase (ALT): 36-121 IU/L
* Aspartate aminotransferase (AST): 36-121 IU/L
* Alkaline phosphatase (Alk Phos): 289-37.8 IU/L
* Amylase: 93 IU/L
* Lipase: <93 IU/L
* Lactic acid: 1.5 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.5 g/dL
* LDH: 663 IU/L
* Calcium (Ca++): 8.6 mg/dL
* Magnesium (Mg++): 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphorus (PO4): 2.4 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest X-ray (CXR): Developing right lower lobe (RLL) infiltrate, persistent left lower lobe (LLL) infiltrate

The patient's medical conditions and potential complications include:

* VAP: The patient's symptoms of fever, increased secretions, and bibasilar infiltrates are consistent with VAP. The patient has been receiving antibiotics for 8 days and will continue to receive daily CXR and pan culture.
* ETOH hepatitis: The patient has a history of ETOH abuse and has developed ETOH hepatitis. The patient has been treated with prednisone, pentoxyphiline, lactulose, rifaximin, and MV, and will continue to receive these medications.
* ETOH withdrawal: The patient has been experiencing withdrawal symptoms and has been treated with haloperidol and ativan. The patient will continue to receive these medications and will be tapered off propofol and weaned off fentanyl.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and has been experiencing tachypnea on pressure support ventilation (PSV). The patient will continue to receive daily PSV trials and VAP treatment.
* Electrolyte abnormalities: The patient has developed hypernatremia, which has been treated with free water boluses. The patient will continue to have electrolyte levels checked and repleted as needed.
* Conjunctivitis: The patient has been treated with erythromycin for conjunctivitis.
* Vaginal discharge: The patient has been treated with metrogel for vaginal discharge and will receive STD screening when extubated and awake.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may continue to deteriorate, requiring further interventions such as mechanical ventilation or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
* Sepsis: The patient's VAP may progress to sepsis, which could lead to multi-organ dysfunction and death.
* Hepatic failure: The patient's ETOH hepatitis may progress to hepatic failure, which could lead to coagulopathy, bleeding, and death.
* Cardiac arrest: The patient's electrolyte abnormalities and cardiac medications may increase the risk of cardiac arrest.
* Neurological complications: The patient's ETOH withdrawal and sedation may lead to neurological complications such as seizures, coma, or death.
* Infection: The patient's VAP and other medical conditions may increase the risk of infection, which could lead to sepsis and death.

   the order of 45%.  Bilirubin continues to elevated at 37.8 now .
   - discontinued steroids today as no improvement in bili on this
   - continue  pentoxiphylline
   - continue daily lactulose and rifaxamin as below
   - continue mvt/thiamine/folate
   - continue tube feeds via OGT
   - trend LFTs, synthetic function daily
   - f/up liver recs, appreciate input
   .
   # Encephalopathy: Most consistent with hepatic encephalopathy and EtoH
   withdrawal. Recent CT head without evidence of any bleeding. Ativan
   tapered down to 6 overnight
   - continue lactulose and rifaxamin
   - try to limit  Fentanyl, continue taper down ativan as tolerates,
   taper at 4 today
   .
   # EtoH withdrawal:
   - Ativan drip tapering as she tolerates ( down from max 8mg/hr to
   6mg/hr now , trial of 4mg/hr today)
   - basal Fentanyl with boluses as needed /  weaning slowly as tolerates
   (75 today)
   - continue on haldol 2mg q8h standing, monitor QTC w/EKG
   - continue mvi/thiamine/folate
   - social work input appreciated, will continue to follow
   .
   # Ventilation: Still remains intubated. [**Month (only) 11**] be secondary to new VAP by
   CXR, increased secretions
   Unable to tolerate SBT [**3-10**] tachypnea
 also may be element of fluid
   overload. She had been intubated for airway protection / AMS.
   - Did not tolerate PSV well so will continue to rest on A/C for today
   to maintain safe airway given extreme AMS and encephalopathy.
   - Keep I/Os with goal -1L negative
 gentle diuresis with PRN 20 IV
   lasix as needed
   - maintaine UOP >40cc/hr
   . .

   to 100.5F and questionable infiltrate overnight on CXR at RLL.
   Lactate elevation has now corrected , but this was likely more related
   to ALF.  Intubation with AMS on admission so need to be weary of
   aspiration PNAs and VAP.  Opted to start therapy overnight as below.
   -continue on Vanco/Cef/Cipro for VAP coverage for now  (day [**3-16**])

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following key points:

1. The patient is a 42-year-old female with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis, who presented with acute fulminant hepatic failure, multiple electrolyte abnormalities, confusion, fevers, and lactate elevation.
2. She is currently intubated for airway protection and is being treated for alcoholic hepatitis, ETOH withdrawal, and VAP.
3. Her liver function tests (LFTs) show elevated bilirubin, and her synthetic function is compromised.
4. She has encephalopathy, which is likely due to hepatic encephalopathy and ETOH withdrawal.
5. She has a history of ETOH withdrawal and is being treated with Ativan, Fentanyl, and Haldol.
6. She has a VAP, which is being treated with Vancomycin, Cefepime, and Ciprofloxacin.
7. She has a UTI, which is being treated with Vancomycin, Cefepime, and Ciprofloxacin.
8. She has anemia, which is being managed with type and screen, transfusion of Hct > 21, and stool guaiacs.
9. She has conjunctivitis, which is being treated with erythromycin eye ointment.
10. She has vaginal discharge, which is being treated with vaginal flagyl.
11. She has peripheral neuropathy, which is being held for now due to sedation.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Further deterioration of liver function, leading to increased risk of bleeding, sepsis, and death.
2. Increased risk of VAP and other respiratory complications due to prolonged intubation.
3. Development of sepsis or septic shock due to UTI or VAP.
4. Increased risk of bleeding due to coagulopathy and thrombocytopenia.
5. Increased risk of aspiration pneumonia due to altered mental status and decreased gag reflex.
6. Development of kidney injury or failure due to dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, or nephrotoxic medications.
7. Increased risk of cardiovascular complications, such as arrhythmias, due to electrolyte imbalance and liver failure.
8. Increased risk of respiratory failure due to prolonged intubation and underlying lung disease.
9. Development of gastrointestinal bleeding due to portal hypertension and coagulopathy.
10. Increased risk of septicemia due to UTI or VAP.

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and adjusting her treatment plan accordingly to prevent or minimize these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   42 year old female with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis who presented
   with acute fulminant hepatic failure with multiple electrolyte
   abnormalities, confusion, fevers, & lactate elevation being treated for
   alcoholic hepatitis and ETOH withdrawal, still intubated for airway
   protection.
   .
   # Bacteremia and VAP
   Sputum and blood with ESBL E coli, still febrile overnight. Possible
   aspiration leading to pna. Also possible urinary source for the
   bacteremia. Foley has been changed.
   - Change to meropenem, anticipate 8d course for VAP
   - DC vanc and cipro
   - Follow up pending cultures and final sensitivites, CIS
   #Alcoholic hepatitis:
   Bilis continue to trend up, did not respond to steroids
   Ultrasound with poor study but patent vasculature and no overt ascites
   noted.  Discriminate function is 63 on admit.  Estimated mortality
   given her degree of elevation in the presence of encephalopathy is on
   the order of 45%.  Bilirubin continues to elevated at 37.8 now .
   - continue  pentoxiphylline
   - continue daily lactulose and rifaxamin as below
   - continue mvt/thiamine/folate
   - continue tube feeds via OGT
   - trend LFTs, synthetic function daily
   - f/up liver recs, appreciate input
   .
   # Encephalopathy: Most consistent with hepatic encephalopathy and EtoH
   withdrawal. Recent CT head without evidence of any bleeding.
   - continue lactulose and rifaxamin
   - try to limit  Fentanyl, continue taper down ativan as tolerates
   .
   # EtoH withdrawal:
   - Ativan drip tapering as she tolerates
   - basal Fentanyl with boluses as needed /  weaning slowly as tolerates
   - continue on haldol 2mg q8h standing, monitor QTC w/EKG
   - continue mvi/thiamine/folate
   - social work input appreciated, will continue to follow
   .
   # Ventilation:
   Still remains intubated. [**Month (only) 11**] be secondary to new VAP by CXR, increased
   secretions
   Unable to tolerate SBT [**3-10**] tachypnea
 also may be element of fluid
   overload. She had been intubated for airway protection / AMS.
   - Reattempt PSV today, consider precedex/extubation tomorrow
   - Keep I/Os with goal -1L negative
 gentle diuresis with PRN 20 IV
   lasix as needed
   .
   # Anemia:
   Pt with baseline anemia, also h/o BRBPR at home though none here. Had
   some oral trauma in setting of intubation causing some additional blood
   loss.  HCt stable at 26-28 range for several days now.
   - active type and screen, transfuse hct>21 or active bleeding
   - check Hcts daily
   - continue PPI
   - stool guaiacs
   .
   # Conjunctivitis: continue topical erythromycin
   .
   # Vaginal discharge: Patient with malodorous vaginal discharge. Was
   started on topical metronidazole. Patient with history of STDs. RPR
   negative
   - continue vaginal flagyl
   - send urine for chlamydia/gonorrhea. Will need HIV testing when awake
   - social work when mental status improved
   # Peripheral neuropathy
   - holding gabapentin for now given sedated
